title: Gordon Seyfried
text:
Gordon Clay Seyfried (born July 4, 1937) is a retired American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="baseball%20player">player</a>. The former right-handed <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> spent 12 years as a professional and appeared in five <a href="games%20pitched">games</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> for the and <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a>. The native of <a href="Long%20Beach%2C%20California">Long Beach, California</a> was listed as and . He attended <a href="Wilson%20Classical%20High%20School">Wilson Classical High School</a> and <a href="Long%20Beach%20City%20College">Long Beach City College</a>.
Seyfried was signed by the <a href="Detroit%20Tigers">Detroit Tigers</a> in 1956. In 1964, "<a href="The%20Sporting%20News">The Sporting News</a>" said his number one pitch was a slider. However, other sources say he threw a knuckleball. In the <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor leagues</a>, he won over 100 games, leading the <a href="Eastern%20League%20%281938%E2%80%932020%29">Eastern League</a> in wins in 1958, with 17, while playing for the <a href="Lancaster%20Red%20Roses">Lancaster Red Roses</a>. From 1960–1962, as a member of the <a href="Triple-A%20%28baseball%29">Triple-A</a> <a href="Denver%20Bears">Denver Bears</a>, he posted a combined <a href="win%E2%80%93loss%20record%20%28pitching%29">won–lost record</a> of 40–24. On November 27, 1962, Seyfried was traded with fellow hurler <a href="Ron%20Nischwitz">Ron Nischwitz</a> to the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a> for veteran <a href="third%20baseman">third baseman</a> <a href="Bubba%20Phillips">Bubba Phillips</a>.
After spending the 1963 minor league season at Triple-A, Seyfried made his <a href="MLB">MLB</a> debut on September 13, 1963, against the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Angels">Los Angeles Angels</a> at <a href="Dodger%20Stadium">Dodger Stadium</a>, only a few miles up the freeway from his Long Beach home town. Relieving <a href="Early%20Wynn">Early Wynn</a>, Seyfried pitched one <a href="innings%20pitched">inning</a> and allowed two <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> and no <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a> before being lifted for a <a href="pinch%20hitter">pinch hitter</a>; Cleveland prevailed in 12 innings, 7–6, with <a href="Gary%20Bell">Gary Bell</a> getting the win. In the third and final game of his 1963 late-season trial, Seyfried received his only big-league <a href="starting%20pitcher">start</a>. Facing the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Athletics">Kansas City Athletics</a> at <a href="Municipal%20Stadium%20%28Kansas%20City%29">Municipal Stadium</a>, Seyfried allowed only one <a href="earned%20run">earned run</a> in 5 innings, but departed the game trailing 2–1; when Cleveland could not rally from behind, Seyfried was tagged with the loss in his only MLB <a href="decision%20%28baseball%29">decision</a>. In 1964, Seyfried worked in two scoreless April relief appearances for the Indians, before returning to Triple-A. He retired as a pitcher in mid-1967, and spent the remainder of that season as the <a href="manager%20%28baseball%29">manager</a> of the <a href="Gulf%20Coast%20Indians">Gulf Coast Indians</a>, Cleveland's <a href="Rookie-level">Rookie-level</a> affiliate.
All told, in five games and 9 innings pitched in the majors, Seyfried allowed only that one earned run for a career <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> of 0.93. He allowed 13 hits and three <a href="bases%20on%20balls">bases on balls</a>. He <a href="strikeout">fanned</a> one hitter, <a href="Gino%20Cimoli">Gino Cimoli</a> of the Athletics, during his start on September 27, 1963.
